manifesto.title: MANIFESTO
manifesto.subtitle: N√öCLEO COLECTIVO
manifesto.p1: We live in a culture of results. Of polished products and finished works. The creative process‚Äîwith its doubts, errors, and discoveries‚Äîoften remains hidden.
manifesto.p2: N√∫cleo Colectivo was born to change that.
manifesto.p3:
We are not a gallery. We are a laboratory.
We are not a portfolio. We are a living archive.
manifesto.p4: We are a cultural system that values the process as much as the result, removing intermediaries to connect contemporary creation with a curious and participatory community.
manifesto.p5: Here, culture is not consumed: it is activated.
manifesto.p6: We work from the intersection of art, technology, and critical thinking, not as a trend, but as a set of tools to explore new forms of creation, learning, and collaboration.
manifesto.p8: We do not seek to homogenize voices or aesthetics. We seek intersections, frictions, and unlikely encounters that generate new ideas.
manifesto.p9: Authorship is not diluted; it expands. The community does not replace the individual; it empowers them.
manifesto.p10: We believe in open platforms, shared knowledge, and systems that grow with those who inhabit them.
manifesto.p11: N√∫cleo Colectivo does not promise answers. It proposes a space to make, think, and connect.
manifesto.p12: This is not a destination. It is an ever-expanding nucleus. And you are invited to be part of it.

ia.audience: Audience: Students, teachers, and academic community in creative fields.
ia.section_1_p1: The AI for Creative Processes Program is a training proposal by N√∫cleo Colectivo that integrates artificial intelligence as a tool for artistic thought, creation, and production from a critical, ethical, and contextual perspective.
ia.section_1_p2: The program sees AI not as a technical end or a substitute for the author, but as a creative assistant that expands the cognitive, expressive, and productive capabilities of creators. Through a research-creation methodology, participants develop real, documented, and presentable projects, aligned with academic and institutional dynamics.
ia.section_1_p3: This proposal addresses the need to strengthen contemporary artistic training through relevant, accessible, and applicable technological tools, without losing focus on human authorship, critical thinking, and cultural responsibility.
ia.section_2_p1: This program is framed within a pedagogical approach focused on creation, research-creation, and social projection. Its programs integrate intensive theory and practice, preparing students for real artistic, cultural, and productive contexts.
ia.section_2_p2: In this context, incorporating artificial intelligence into creative processes is a strategic opportunity to:
section_2_list: Update training practices in light of emerging technologies.
Expand tools for artistic creation and production.
Strengthen cross-cutting skills in critical thinking, experimentation, and process documentation.
Generate tangible and communicable artistic results.
ia.section_2_p3: The AI for Creative Processes Program aligns with the institutional mission to train sensitive, reflective, and innovative professionals capable of making a cultural and social impact through their creative practices.
ia.section_3_obj_general_text: To design and implement a training program that enables students and teachers to integrate artificial intelligence into their creative and research-creation processes, generating documented, critical, and contextualized artistic projects.
section_3_obj_specific_list: Introduce fundamental concepts of artificial intelligence applied to artistic creation.
Develop practical skills for the conscious use of AI tools in image, sound, text, and narrative.
Foster experimentation, iteration, and critical thinking in creative processes.
Promote conscious authorship, ethics, and reflection on the use of emerging technologies.
Generate creative projects and process logs as evidence of learning.
section_4_list: Students from the faculties of Visual and Multimedia Practices.
ia.section_4_p1: It can also include teachers and graduates interested in creation processes with emerging technologies. No prior knowledge of artificial intelligence is required.
section_5_list: Learning by doing: production is a condition of learning.
AI as a support tool for the creative process, not as a substitute for the author.
Valuation of process, experimentation, and error as sources of knowledge.
ia.section_6_p1: Each session of the program combines:
section_6_list: Socialization of results and collective feedback.
ia.section_6_p2: The methodology is designed to be adaptable to different artistic disciplines, maintaining a common core and allowing variations in deliverables according to the faculty or program.

ia-y-memoria.title: AI & Memory
ia-y-memoria.title_long: Algorithmic Memories: Artificial intelligence and narratives of the past
ia-y-memoria.description: Projects that use artificial intelligence to reinterpret historical archives, generate new memories, or question our relationship with the past.
ia-y-memoria.intro: The incorporation of artificial intelligence into the processes of memory construction has profoundly transformed our relationship with the past. Far from functioning solely as a tool for automation or archiving, AI now acts as an interpretive agent, capable of reorganizing, translating, and generating narratives from large vol√∫menes of historical, visual, sound, and textual data. In this context, memory is no longer understood as a fixed record but as a dynamic, unstable, and contested process.
ia-y-memoria.p1: The AI & Memory collection brings together projects that employ algorithmic systems to reinterpret historical archives, activate latent memories, and question the ways in which the past is preserved, narrated, and transmitted. These practices do not seek to replace human memory, but to challenge it: they expose its gaps, biases, and silences, while proposing new forms of critical reading of the archive.
ia-y-memoria.p2: From a conceptual perspective, artificial intelligence functions here as a cultural mediation technology. Machine learning models do not 'remember' in the human sense of the term; they operate based on patterns, probabilities, and correlations. However, when trained with historical materials‚Äîphotographs, documents, testimonies, audiovisual records, and oral tradition‚Äîthey produce representations that force us to ask who remembers, what is remembered, and under what criteria collective memory is constructed.
ia-y-memoria.p3: These works show that every archive is political. The selection of data, digitalization processes, curatorial decisions, and the algorithms themselves respond to specific social and cultural contexts. In this sense, AI is not neutral: it amplifies both dominant discourses and structural absences. The collection embraces this tension as a field of critical work, proposing projects that make visible what is omitted, fragmented, and unsaid, and that open space for alternative memories.

case_study.title: Case Study
case_study.subtitle: Cosiaca 350 / An immersive journey into the history of Medell√≠n
case_study.p1: Cosiaca 350 is an emblematic project within the AI & Memory axis, as it articulates historical research, oral tradition, and contemporary technologies to explore the 'paisa' identity from a critical and playful perspective. El proyecto surge de una indagaci√≥n sobre la figura hist√≥rica de Jos√© Garc√≠a, alias Cosiaca, personaje popular del siglo XIX que encarna la astucia, el humor irreverente y la oralidad como forma de resistencia cultural.
case_study.p2: More than a traditional historiographical reconstruction, Cosiaca 350 proposes memory as an expanded narrative territory, where the past is reactivated through strategies of fiction, interaction, and public participation. Artificial intelligence plays a central role here as a cultural translation device, capable of mediating between the historical archive and contemporary forms of narrative consumption.
case_study.main_axes_title: The project unfolds as a transmedia universe composed of three main axes:
case_study.list_item_1: Narrative podcast: A sound series that fictionalizes historical encounters, mixing documented facts with speculative imagination. The podcast operates as an extension of the oral tradition, moving the popular story into the digital format and reinforcing memory as an auditory and collective experience.
case_study.list_item_2: Interactive web game with AI: A digital environment where the user dialogues with an artificial version of Cosiaca. This character, built from historical research and linguistic patterns, does not seek to simulate an absolute truth, but to stage the tensions between memory, fiction, and technology. The conversation becomes a performative act: each interaction produces a different version of the past.
case_study.list_item_3: Audiovisual pieces for social media: Micro-stories designed for digital circulation that fragment and redistribute memory in brief formats. These pieces function as cultural dissemination capsules, activating the archive in the present and expanding the narrative to new audiences.
case_study.p4: From the curatorial approach of AI & Memory, Cosiaca 350 exemplifies how artificial intelligence can be used to reactivate the archive without fetishizing it, keeping the technological mediation and its limits visible. AI is not presented as a guarantor of authenticity, but as a tool that evidences the narrative construction of all historical memory.
case_study.p5: The project also poses fundamental ethical questions: what does it mean to give an algorithmic voice to a historical character?, how can we avoid the crystallization of cultural stereotypes?, where is the line between homage, reinterpretation, and simulation? In response, Cosiaca 350 bets on narrative transparency, conscious play, and the user's critical participation.
case_study.p6: In this sense, the project embodies one of the central principles of the collection: understanding memory not as an act of passive conservation, but as a living, situated, and constantly rewritten practice. Cosiaca 350 demuestra que la IA puede ser una aliada para explorar identidades locales, siempre que se asuma como un medio cultural y no como una autoridad hist√≥rica.

arte-interactivo.title: Interactive Art & Perception
arte-interactivo.title_long: Interactive Art and Perception: Curatorial Foundations
arte-interactivo.description: Works that invite the public to participate, modifying the piece with their presence or actions, exploring new forms of sensory and cognitive experience.
arte-interactivo.intro: Interactive art redefines the traditional relationship between work, spectator, and author by shifting the aesthetic experience from passive contemplation to active participation. In this field, the work is not presented as a closed object, but as an open system that is activated, transformed, or completed based on the presence, the body, the decisions, or the actions of the public. Desde esta perspectiva, la percepci√≥n deja de ser un proceso meramente visual para convertirse en una experiencia multisensorial, cognitiva y relacional. The spectator no longer ‚Äúobserves‚Äù the work: they inhabit it, alter it, and co-produce it. Each interaction introduces a variation, causing the work to exist in multiple possible states, always situated in the here and now of the encounter. Interactive art explores how the senses, attention, memory, and movement influence the construction of meaning. Physical interfaces, digital systems, sensors, algorithms, sound, image, and data are articulated to generate dynamic perceptual environments, where the experience emerges from the dialogue between technology and the human body. In this context, the perception is not fixed or universal, but contingent, subjective, and mutable. These practices question the boundaries between the material and the immaterial, the analog and the digital, the human and the technological. The work becomes an experiential device, closer to a laboratory than a traditional art object. Error, improvisation, and the unexpected response of the system are a constitutive part of the creative process. From a cognitive approach, interactive art highlights that perceiving is also interpreting, deciding, and acting. The interaction activates complex mental processes: anticipation, learning, empathy, body awareness, and critical reflection on the technological environment we inhabit. As√≠, la experiencia est√©tica se expande hacia una experiencia de conocimiento. La colecci√≥n Arte Interactivo y Percepci√≥n re√∫ne obras y proyectos que investigan estas tensiones y posibilidades, proponiendo al p√∫blico no solo una experiencia sensorial, sino una toma de conciencia sobre su propio rol dentro de los sistemas que atraviesan la vida contempor√°nea. Aqu√≠, el arte funciona como un espacio de exploraci√≥n perceptiva, donde la tecnolog√≠a no es un fin, sino un medio para repensar c√≥mo sentimos, entendemos y construimos el mundo.

cocreation.title: Active Participation and Co-creation
cocreation.p1: In interactive art, the spectator ceases to be a passive observer and becomes a user, participant, or even a programmer of the work. Rodrigo Alonso se√±ala que, en sentido amplio, 'toda obra interactiva es participativa' porque requiere necesariamente 'la colaboraci√≥n entre su autor, el dispositivo tecnol√≥gico, y un usuario.' That is, the public is part of a creative triangle along with the artist and technology. El usuario's incorporaci√≥n suele darse a trav√©s de dispositivos que reaccionan a sus acciones: como apunta Alonso, 'la forma m√°s b√°sica de hacer consciente al usuario de su participaci√≥n es introducirlo en la obra mediante alg√∫n dispositivo que reaccione directamente a sus actos'. For example, a motion sensor, a microphone, or a camera is enough for the visitor's physical presence to immediately alter what is projected: the mouse arrow that signals our presence on the screen is an elementary case, but interactive installations usually replace it with creative means‚Äîimages, sound, algorithms‚Äîthat visualize each user's gesture.
cocreation.p2: This activation of the public converts the work into a dialogical process. As Ernest Edmonds and Stroud Cornock se√±alaron en los a√±os 70, se configura un 'sistema art√≠stico' din√°mico en el cual 'el artista, la audiencia y el objeto [‚Ä¶] est√°n involucrados activamente en la creaci√≥n de la obra.' The meaning of the piece is constructed through this exchange: interaction is the very medium of the creative process, not just a trigger for something to happen. In practice, the user can literally appear within the work (e.g., their silhouette captured in real-time) or be transformed into visual or sound codes. Paradigm works like Rafael Lozano-Hemmer's Pulse Room (2006) make this co-creation evident: by taking each visitor's heart rate, it projects it as a flickering light in the room, so that 'the public's participation becomes essential to complete the work.' In this way, the visitor not only modifies the work by their presence but also literally constitutes its content. In sum, the interactive piece invites the public to collaborate actively in its definition, blurring the boundary between the finished work and the open process of its gestation.

experience.title: New Sensory and Cognitive Experiences
experience.p1: Interactive works open up new forms of aesthetic experience, integrating the spectator's senses, body, and thought. At a sensory level, they combine visual, auditory, tactile, and even olfactory stimuli to immerse the user in multi-dimensional environments. Onionlab describe que estas instalaciones 'tienen la capacidad de cambiar la forma en que la gente percebe el arte' al hacerlos part√≠cipes del proceso creativo, generando 'una experiencia atractiva y personal que enciende la imaginaci√≥n.' By simultaneously activating several sensory channels, interactive art produces a state of inmersi√≥n where perception is amplified: as Rodrigo Alonso comenta, el color, la imagen, el texto y el sonido se conjugan de modo que la participaci√≥n del p√∫blico se convierte 'en una experiencia a la vez sensorial y conceptual'.
experience.p2: The interactive work can also alter our perception of space and time. La convivencia del elemento f√≠sico con datos digitales en tiempo real disuelve los l√≠mites entre lo real y lo virtual: Alonso subraya que esta interrelaci√≥n arquitect√≥nica y tecnol√≥gica 'induce la reconsideraci√≥n de los l√≠mites entre realidad y artificio', haciendo que los entornos sensibles sean m√°s fluidos y abiertos a lo impredecible. In definitiva, el usuario vive una experiencia multisensorial intensificada: cada acci√≥n genera consecuencias inmediatas (cambios de color, de sonido, de forma) que se integran en un continuo de est√≠mulos. Este giro sensorial es la base de nuevas vivencias est√©ticas donde el acto de percepci√≥n ya no es pasivo sino activo y creativo.
experience.p3: At a cognitive level, interactive works pose new mental challenges. El espectador debe explorar din√°micas no determin√≠sticas, descubrir reglas emergentes y construirse un sentido propio de la pieza. La te√≥rica de interacci√≥n Lucy Suchman destaca que en estos sistemas 'la acci√≥n es central y las metas son emergentes': los usuarios 'alcanzan' el significado de la obra a trav√©s de sus propios encuentros con ella. In other words, the value of the installation arises from the user's behavior and decisions in real time. Este proceso se vincula con la idea de arte como conocimiento vivido: la interacci√≥n es 'no simplemente un medio para activar la obra, sino un veh√≠culo para la reflexi√≥n y la producci√≥n de conocimiento'. From this perspective, the artistic system functions as a ‚Äúliving laboratory‚Äù (similar to the Powerhouse Museum's Beta_space project), where each visitor collaborates with their actions in the generation of meaning. As√≠, m√°s all√° de un goce est√©tico pasivo, el p√∫blico asume un rol cognitivo activo: pregunta, indaga, espera o reconoce patrones, desarrollando una experiencia intelectual personalizada en cada encuentro con la obra.

references.title: Relevant Artists, Theorists, and Currents
references.p1: In the curatorship of Interactive Art and Perception, various references from practice and theory are supported. En el √°mbito art√≠stico, destacan creadores contempor√°neos que exploran la interacci√≥n y la percepci√≥n multisensorial. For example, Rafael Lozano-Hemmer (Mexico-Canada) is known for installations that combine biometric sensors with light and sound effects. Su obra Pulse Room (2006) registra los latidos cardiacos de los visitantes y los traduce en un mar de bombillas parpadeantes, de modo que la pulsaci√≥n vital de cada persona se convierte en elemento visual y sensorial. Grupos como teamLab (Jap√≥n) han popularizado entornos digitales inmersivos (realidad aumentada/virtual) donde los movimientos del p√∫blico alteran patrones de proyecci√≥n sobre las paredes. Del mismo modo, pioneros como Christa Sommerer & Laurent Mignonneau (Austria-Francia) han desarrollado desde los 90 instalaciones interactivas basadas en c√°maras y sensores (por ejemplo, obras que traducen gestos corporales en formas org√°nicas en pantalla). Otros referentes incluyen a Random International (UK), con obras como Rain Room (donde caminar bajo lluvia requiere de la presence humana para detener el agua) y artistas generativos como Camille Utterback o Golan Levin, cuyas obras de software transforman los gestos del usuario en arte visual y sonoro en tiempo real. Aunque no se citen todas exhaustivamente, estos ejemplos ilustran la variedad de aproximaciones: desde instalaciones de gran escala hasta experiencias √≠ntimas, siempre integrando la percepci√≥n del p√∫blico como materia prima.
references.p2: On the theoretical level, the collection is based on concepts that link participation, perception, and aesthetics. En primer lugar, la fenomenolog√≠a de Maurice Merleau-Ponty proporciona una visi√≥n clave: √©l considera que la percepci√≥n es pre-reflexiva y corporal, de modo que sujeto y objeto se entrelazan ¬´en un entretejido donde objeto y sujeto son interdependientes¬ª. Under this perspective, interactive art is explained as an extension of our perceptual body: la obra no es un mero objeto representado, sino que participa de la construcci√≥n misma de la experiencia del mundo. In line with this, Nicolas Bourriaud ‚Äìte√≥rico de la est√©tica relacional‚Äì define el arte contempor√°neo como ¬´organizaci√≥n de presencia compartida entre objetos, im√°genes y gente¬ª. Para Bourriaud, la obra es un espacio social: el espectador ya no es receptor pasivo, sino agente activo cuya interacci√≥n constituye el sentido. In fact, in his perspective, current art serves as a ¬´laboratorio de formas vivas que cualquiera puede apropiar¬ª, enfatizando el juego comunitario y la co-interpretaci√≥n. Desde la teor√≠a de los nuevos medios, figuras como Edmonds and Cornock laid academic foundations: en los 70 propusieron el concepto de la ‚Äúmatriz art√≠stica‚Äù, se√±alando que en las obras interactivas todos los componentes (artista, p√∫blico, medio tecnol√≥gico) cooperan; la interactividad es entonces el propio proceso creativo. This idea is also taken up in human-computer interaction studies: for example, Lucy Suchman enfatiza que en estos entornos ¬´la acci√≥n es central y las metas son emergentes¬ª, de modo que el significado se construye en cada acci√≥n del usuario. Otro investigador, S√∂ke Dinkla, vincula el arte interactivo actual con los experimentos participativos de los 60 (happenings, cine expandido), destacando su naturaleza ¬´h√≠brida¬ª: seg√∫n ella, pese a la sofisticaci√≥n t√©cnica, el arte interactivo ¬´no se basa en objetos cuya relevancia sea visual; [‚Ä¶] el material art√≠stico est√° constituido por el di√°logo entre el programa y el usuario¬ª. Finalmente, estudios recientes (como la tesis sobre entornos sensoriales interactivos de Mar√≠a T. Alonso Acebes) subrayan que estas obras generan experiencias inmersivas, sensoriales e intelectuales, en las que la participaci√≥n es crucial para crear significado. De este modo, convergen diversas corrientes ‚Äìfenomenolog√≠a, est√©tica relacional, arte generativo, interfaz hombre-m√°quina‚Äì que sit√∫an al espectador en el centro del fen√≥meno art√≠stico.
references.p3: Interactive art is defined as a form of artistic expression that involves the active collaboration of the public in the creation of the work. Seg√∫n StudySmarter, esta modalidad ¬´permite la participaci√≥n activa del espectador en el proceso creativo, convirti√©ndolo en co-creador de la obra¬ª. By means of digital technologies, sensors, and interfaces, interactive art generates dynamic and personalized experiences that directly link the public with the piece. En esta convergencia de arte y tecnolog√≠a se redefinen los l√≠mites de lo tradicional, enfatiz√°ndose la importancia de lo sensorial y emocional en la apreciaci√≥n art√≠stica. The 'Interactive Art and Perception' collection in the N√∫cleo Colectivo project (curated by Manuel Palacio) is based on this principle: la obra ya no es un objeto est√°tico, sino un espacio de encuentro donde el espectador juega un rol central en su significado.

conclusion.title: Curatorial Conclusions
conclusion.p1: El enfoque curatorial de Manuel Palacio para la colecci√≥n ‚ÄúArte Interactivo y Percepci√≥n‚Äù se apoya en estos ejes conceptuales: participaci√≥n activa, experiencia multisensorial y visi√≥n te√≥rica. The selection of works will aim for pieces where the technology involved multiplies the senses (visual, sound, tactile) and encourages conscious public involvement. Siguiendo las fuentes citadas, la curadur√≠a valorar√° proyectos generativos que integren datos reales o IA, instalaciones inmersivas que involucren el cuerpo en el espacio y estructuras abiertas de significado. In this context, the curator acts more as a facilitator of creative encounters than as a sole author: he is inspired by the idea of the museum as a ‚Äúliving laboratory‚Äù where interaction enriches both the visitor and the art itself.
conclusion.p2: In sum, the proposed curatorial basis considera que el arte interactivo transforma la funci√≥n del espectador, disolviendo las barreras entre lo visible y lo vivido. By turning the aesthetic experience into a participatory process, an emotional and intellectual bond is built with the work, giving rise to new forms of artistic understanding. Estas perspectivas te√≥ricas y pr√°cticas sustentan la colecci√≥n, garantizando que ‚ÄúArte Interactivo y Percepci√≥n‚Äù se configure como un corpus coherente de obras que despliegan activamente la percepci√≥n del p√∫blico y redefinen la experiencia est√©tica en la era digital.

references_footer.title: References
references_footer.content: La discusi√≥n anterior integra ideas y citas de textos relevantes sobre arte interactivo y percepci√≥n, as√≠ como ejemplos de artistas contempor√°neos reconocidos en este campo. Cada cita aporta sustento te√≥rico y contextualiza el enfoque curatoral de la colecci√≥n en N√∫cleo Colectivo.

perception.title: Perception
perception.text: En el arte interactivo la percepci√≥n es un acto corporal y situado. Seg√∫n la fenomenolog√≠a de Merleau-Ponty, el cuerpo vivido es el medio de toda experiencia sensorial. In this framework, the interactive work extends the spectator's body into the artistic space, induciendo a que ‚Äúsujeto y objeto se mezclen y coexistan‚Äù en un entretejido de sentido. This means that art is not limited to representing the world, but actively participates in its perceptual construction.

interaction.title: Interaction
interaction.text: Implica di√°logo din√°mico. Interactive art uses interfaces (sensors, cameras, touch screens, mobile devices, etc.) for the piece to respond to the public's gestures, sounds, or movements. No son obras est√°ticas; deben mutar en funci√≥n del usuario y su entorno. A 'dialogue between the work and the spectator' is established, haciendo que cada visita sea irrepetible. In this sense, la interacci√≥n redefine la experiencia est√©tica en forma de intercambio vivo.

generative.title: Generative Art
generative.text: Se refiere a pr√°cticas algor√≠tmicas aut√≥nomas. Generative art is created through computational systems that operate (semi)aut√≥nomamente, reduciendo la intervenci√≥n manual del artista. In essence, the creator defines rules and parameters, mientras que the system genera de forma impredecible formas, im√°genes o sonidos. This symbiosis means the final result emerges from human-machine collaboration. Many generative works incorporate real-time data and sensors, so the public can modify variables through gestures, voice, or movement. As√≠, lo generativo empuja la interactividad hacia la aleatoriedad guiada: por ejemplo, un algoritmo puede cambiar un paisaje sonoro seg√∫n la posici√≥n de los visitantes, produciendo un flujo sensorial nuevo en cada iteraci√≥n.

installation.title: Installation
installation.text: Forma art√≠stica de car√°cter espacial e inmersivo. An interactive installation convenes a complete architectural space, integrando im√°genes, luces, sonido y estructuras f√≠sicas. Como explica Rodrigo Alonso, estas obras ‚Äúponen en interrelaci√≥n un espacio f√≠sico ‚Äìhabitado por los cuerpos y las acciones de los usuarios‚Äì con un conjunto de datos, operaciones y traducciones num√©ricas que modifican el entorno sensible‚Äù. That is, they combine the material (pavement, walls, objects) with the digital (projections, live data) to create a coherent environment. El usuario se desplaza en √©l como parte de la obra, reformulando su percepci√≥n espacial y temporal.

technology.title: Technology
technology.text: Herramienta mediadora. The use of digital technology ‚Äìordenadores, sensores biom√©tricos, c√°maras de captura de movimiento, realidad virtual/aumentada, inteligencia artificial, etc.‚Äì is essential in interactive art. Gracias a estos recursos, el artista designs sistemas en que los datos del entorno o del cuerpo influyen continuamente en la obra. For example, 3D cameras can map the public's shape to generate volumetric images, mientras que algoritmos de IA pueden reinterpretar las entradas del usuario creando nuevos efectos sonoros o visuales. In a word, technology acts as a mediator between the spectator and the work, amplificando los est√≠mulos sensoriales y ofreciendo m√∫ltiples niveles de interacci√≥n (local o incluso colectiva en l√≠nea).

experience.title: Aesthetic Experience
experience.text: Se refiere a la vivencia del p√∫blico. In this context, aesthetics emerges from the participatory process. Como apunta Onionlab, al permitir la interacci√≥n el arte deviene ¬´una conversaci√≥n animada entre la visi√≥n del artista y la interpretaci√≥n del observador, disolviendo las l√≠neas que distinguen el arte de la realidad¬ª. The result is a personal and memorable experience: cada usuario construye significados propios. La interacci√≥n ¬´enciende la imaginaci√≥n¬ª del espectador, creando un lazo emocional y cognitivo con la obra. As√≠, la dimensi√≥n est√©tica reside menos en la contemplaci√≥n distante y m√°s en el v√≠nculo activo; el arte se vivencia como un evento √∫nico donde el sentido se co-genera entre todos los participantes.
